Package edu.waketech.csc251.tools

Interface Screener<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - Type of object to be screened
    public interface Screener<T>

    Often we want to divide a collection of objects into subsets based on some criteria, but we don't want to modify our data store each time a new subsetting requirement emerges. Screener objects provide a generalized way to achieve both desires--allowing for new and arbitrary subsetting requests to be defined, and avoiding modifying the data store for each new request. It is the application writer that specifies the specific test for each object of the collection. Those objects that pass the test are included in the subset. Those that fail the test are rejected from the subset. The data store, when given the application's test, can apply the test to each member of the collection and perform the subsetting operation.

    Other names for this type of function are "Filter" and "Predicate."

    Let's say I have a collection of flowers. Flower objects have a getColor method that returns "red," "yellow," "blue," etc. They also have a getType method that returns "rose," "carnation," "daisy," etc. One customer might want to view all of the red flowers, another might want to view everything except the yellow flowers. Another might want to view all of the roses, whatever the color.

    For the customer wanting to see all red flowers, we could write a class

    class RedScreener implements Screener<Flower>
    with a test method that returns
    objToTest.getColor().equals("red")
    This test method returns true for all red flowers, and false for all others. We could run a RedScreener object's test method on each flower in our collection. The flowers to be included in the "all red flowers" subset will be identified by test returning true. Flowers to be excluded will be identified by test returning false.

    For the customer wanting to see all flowers that are any color except yellow, we would implement Screener
    class NotYellowScreener implements Screener<Flower>
    and the test method would return
    !objToTest.getColor().equals("yellow")
    This test method returns false for all yellow flowers, and true for all others. We could run a NotYellowScreener object's test method on each flower in our collection. The flowers to be included in the "not yellow flowers" subset will be identified by test returning true. Flowers to be excluded will be identified by test returning false.

    To select all of the roses in our flower collection, we would implement
    class RoseScreener implements Screener<Flower>
    with a test method that returns
    objToTest.getType().equals("rose")
    This test method returns true for all roses, and false for all others. We could run the RoseScreener object's test method on each flower in our collection. The flowers to be included in the "roses" subset will be identified by test returning true. Flowers to be excluded will be identified by test returning false.

    For each of these examples, we would test each Flower object using the test method of the appropriate Screener object. If the test method returns true, that flower is a member of our "interesting" subset. If test returns false, that flower is not a member of our interesting subset.

    Author:
    parks
    See Also:
    DataSetGeneric.getList(Screener)

      boolean test​(T objToTest)
      Determine whether the given object passes, or fails to pass, the screen.

      • test

        boolean test​(T objToTest)
        Determine whether the given object passes, or fails to pass, the screen.
        Parameters:
        objToTest - will be examined to determine if it passes our screen
        Returns:
        true if the object passes our screen, false otherwise
